'Vazgen Sargsyan' (, ) (March 5, 1959 â October 27, 1999) was an Armenian
military commander and politician. Sargsyan joined the movement for the
unification of Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast with Armenia in the late 1980s
and led the Armenian volunteers during the early clashes with the Azerbaijanis.
In 1990, Sargsyan became the head of the Defence Committee of the Armenian
parliament. After Armenia's declaration of independence in September 1991, he
was appointed Defence Minister of Armenia by President Levon Ter-Petrosyan. The
inter-ethnic conflict escalated into a full-scale war by 1992. In August 1992,
Sargsyan organized and led an irregular battalion which turned the course of the
war in favor of the Armenian side. Sargsyan is considered the main commander of
the Armenian forces during the war. From 1992 to 1995 he served as Presidential
Adviser on Defence Affairs, Presidential Envoy to Border Regions of Armenia and
State Minister on Defence, Security and Internal Affairs. The Nagorno-Karabakh
War ended in May 1994 with the Armenian forces establishing de facto control of
the disputed area. From 1995 to 1999 Sargsyan served as Defence Minister, during
which he laid the groundwork to establish a regular army.

In February 1998, extremely influential Defence Minister Vazgen Sargsyan forced
President Levon Ter-Petrosyan to resign due to disagreements around the
settlement policies over Karabakh. With Sargsyan's support, Robert Kocharyan was
elected president in March 1998. However, their relations did not last long and
by early 1999, Vazgen Sargsyan had merged Yerkrapah, the prominent group of
Karabakh war veterans, into the Republican Party of Armenia to form a political
base in the parliament. Sargsyan then joined Armenia's former Soviet leader
Karen Demirchyan to form an alliance prior to the parliamentary election. Their
Unity bloc won effective majority to the National Assembly in May 30, 1999
election. Sargsyan became the Prime Minister of Armenia on June 11, 1999
emerging as the de facto decision-maker in Armenia with strong hold on the
military and the government institutions.

Vazgen Sargsyan, along with Karen Demirchyan and several others, was
assassinated in the Armenian parliament shooting on October 27, 1999. Although
the assassination perpetrators were sentenced to lifetime in prison, there is a
public distrust toward the trial process. Experts and politicians argue that
their assassination was a conspiracy involving President Robert Kocharyan and
National Security Serzh Sargsyan. Others have speculated the possible
involvement of Russia, the Armenian Revolutionary Federation or the Western
powers in the shooting.

Vazgen Sargsyan is widely recognized as the founder of the Armenian Army, which
concluded a victorious war with Azerbaijan over the Armenian-populated Nagorno-
Karabakh. Today, his contribution to the establishment of an independent
Armenian state and ensuring its security are greatly valued. Sargsyan
was awarded with the highest titles of Armenia and Nagorno-KarabakhâNational
Hero of Armenia (posthumously) and Hero of Artsakh (1998). Streets, schools,
parks, the Yerevan military academy and the Republican Stadium are named after
him, numerous statues have been erected in his memory. Several polls from 2006
to 2008 by Gallup showed Sargsyan leading the list of national heroes in the
public perception in Armenia.
